Scripting¶

The scripting functionality allows you to write Python scripts that can directly control (and read from) the rest of the program with simple commands. This allows the creation of complex experimental sequences such as multi-dimensional scans, conditional calibration sequences, averaging, or really whatever you can come up with.

The scripting interface

The available script commands are listed on the right hand side, together with documentation. In addition, all normal Python functionality is available. The console output shows console messages pertaining to the script only.

The buttons do the following:

- start the script

- pause the script

- stop the script

- pause the script and the scan, if one is running

- stop the script and the scan, if one is running

- open an existing script

- save the script (CTRL-S)

- create a new script

- add a 0.4 s delay between each script command (potentially useful for debugging)

- run the script in a loop (i.e. restart when it finishes)

There are a number of example scripts in IonControl\config\Scripts.

Warning

If a script contains an infinite loop (or a potentially infinite loop), you must include the following lines in the loop:

if scriptIsStopped():
    break

If you do not, and the loop is infinite, you will be unable to stop the script without stopping the whole program.

Available script functions¶

class Script(fullname='', code='', parent=None)[source]
abortScan()[source]

Abort the scan.

This is equivalent to clicking “abort” on the experiment GUI.

addGlobal(name, value, unit)[source]

add a global ‘name’, set to (value, unit).

This is equivalent to adding a global via the globals UI,and then setting its value in the globals table.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – name of the global to add
  • value (float) – value to set it to
  • unit (str) – unit to use
addPlot(name)[source]

Add a plot named “name”.

This is equivalent to clicking “add plot” on the experiment GUI. If ‘name’ already exists, does nothing.

Parameters:name (str) – name of plot to add
closeTrace(traceName)[source]

Finalize trace. Registers in the measurement log and saves. No new data can be added to the trace.

If this function is not called on a trace, it will be closed automatically when the script ends.

Parameters:traceName (str) – name of trace to close
consolePrint(*args, **kwds)[source]

consolePrint(message, error=False, color=’‘): write a message to the console.

Parameters:
  • message (str) – the message to print
  • error (bool) – If True, message prints in red
  • color (str) – color to print in if error is False, HTML color names accepted
createTrace(traceName, plotName, xUnit='', xLabel='', comment='')[source]

create a new trace

Parameters:
  • traceName (str) – name of new trace
  • plotName (str) – plot to plot it on
  • xUnit (str) – unit for x axis
  • xLabel (str) – label for x axis
  • comment (str) – comment for trace file
Raises:

ScriptException – if plotName is not a plot
fit(fitName, traceName)[source]

Fit trace using specified fit. :param traceName: name of trace to fit :type traceName: str :param fitName: name of fit settings to use (from fit GUI) :type fitName: str

getAllData()[source]

Get the full set of data from the most recent scan.

Returns:all data from most recent scan. key: name of each evaluation in the evaluation list. val: tuple (xList, yList).
Return type:dict
getAnalysis()[source]

Get the analysis results for the most recent scan.

Returns:analysis results as dictionary of dictionaries. key: to the name of each analysis in the analysis list. val: Another dictionary. Inner key: names of fit parameters in the specified evaluation. Inner val: fit value of that parameter
Return type:dict

Example

A Gaussian fit named “myFit” in the analysis, with center parameter ‘x0’, would return its best fit center value as:

getAnalysis()[‘myFit’][‘x0’]

getData()[source]

Get the most recent data point from a running scan.

Returns:data from running scan. key: the name of each evaluation in the evaluation list. val: tuple (x, y).
Return type:dict
getFit()[source]

Get the fit results for the most recent scan.

Returns:fit results as dictionary. key: to the name of the parameter val: fit value of that parameter
Return type:dict

Example

A Gaussian fit named “myFit” in the analysis, with center parameter ‘x0’, would return its best fit center value as:

getFit[‘x0’]

getGlobal(name)[source]

get current value of global ‘name’

getScanStatus()[source]

Return the current state of the scan.

Returns:One of ‘idle’, ‘running’, ‘paused’, ‘starting’, ‘stopping’, or ‘interrupted’
Return type:str
loadVoltageDef(fileName, path='')[source]

Load a waveform and its associated shuttling.xml file. :param fileName: name of waveform including the ‘.txt’ :type fileName: str :param path: path to the fileName :type path: str

pauseScan()[source]

Pause the scan.

This is equivalent to clicking “pause” on the experiment GUI.

pauseScript()[source]

Pause the script.

This is equivalent to clicking the “pause script” button.

plotList(xList, yList, traceName, overwrite=False, plotStyle=-1)[source]

Plot a set of points given in xList, yList to trace traceName.

Parameters:
  • x (list[float]) – x coordinates
  • y (list[float]) – y coordinates
  • traceName (str) – name of trace to use
  • overwrite (bool) – if True, overwrite existing data
  • plotStyle (int) –
    plot with lines, points, etc...
    0: lines 1: points 2: linespoints 3: lines errors 4: points errors 5: linespoints errors

    otherwise: GUI default
Raises:
  • ScriptException – if traceName is not a trace
  • ScriptException – if x and y are of unequal lengths
plotPoint(x, y, traceName, plotStyle=-1)[source]

Plot a single point (x, y) to trace traceName.

Parameters:
  • x (float) – x coordinate
  • y (float) – y coordinate
  • traceName (str) – name of trace to use
  • plotStyle (int) –
    plot with lines, points, etc...
    0: lines 1: points 2: linespoints 3: lines errors 4: points errors 5: linespoints errors

    otherwise: GUI default
Raises:

ScriptException – if traceName is not a trace
pushToNamedTrace(topNode, child, row, data, col='y')[source]

Push some data to a Named Trace. col specifies x or y data but can be a trace column dict key if desired.

Returns:True
Return type:bool
scanRunning()[source]

Determine if scan is running.

Returns:True if the scan is running. Otherwise, False.
Return type:bool
scriptIsStopped()[source]

Determine if script is stopped.

Returns:True if the script has been stopped, Otherwise, False.
Return type:bool
setAnalysis(name)[source]

set the analysis settings to “name.”

This is equivalent to selecting “name” from the analysis settings drop down menu.

Parameters:name (str) – name of the analysis settings to set
Raises:ScriptException – if there is no analysis by that name
setEvaluation(name)[source]

set the evaluation settings to “name.”

This is equivalent to selecting “name” from the evaluation settings drop down menu.

Parameters:name (str) – name of the evaluation settings to set
Raises:ScriptException – if there is no evaluation by that name
setGlobal(name, value, unit)[source]

set global ‘name’ to (value, unit).

This is equivalent to typing in a value/unit in the globals table.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – name of the global to change
  • value (float) – value to set it to
  • unit (str) – unit to use
Raises:

ScriptException – if there is not a global with the given name. This is to avoid typos leading to unexpected behavior. To add a global, use ‘addGlobal’
setScan(name)[source]

set the scan settings to “name.”

This is equivalent to selecting “name” from the scan settings drop down menu.

Parameters:name (str) – name of the scan settings to set
Raises:ScriptException – if there is no scan by that name
startScan(globalOverrides=list(), wait=True)[source]

Start the scan.

This is equivalent to clicking “start” on the experiment GUI. Optionally a list of (name, magnitude) tuples or (name, (value, unit)) tuples can be given that overrides global variables during the scan. If wait=True, the script will not continue until the scan is finished.

globalOverrides: list((name, value)) or list((name, (value, unit))) wait: bool

stopScan()[source]

Stop the scan.

This is equivalent to clicking “stop” on the experiment GUI.

stopScript()[source]

Stop the script.

This is equivalent to clicking the “stop script” button.

waitForScan()[source]

Wait for scan to finish before continuing script.

If startScan is run with wait=True, this function is unnecessary.
